bibl.title: Military Orders for Walter Reed, November 1, 1901

div1.p: Sternberg states Reed cannot be spared from his duties as a professor in the Army Medical School to attend a medical conference in Michigan. A letter from the Adjutant General to R. P. Bishop informs him and copies the other congressmen who had petitioned the Secretary of War for Reed's attendance at the conference. Endorsements are also enclosed, dated October 31 and November 1, 1901. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

November 1, 1901.
Respectfully returned to the
Adjutant General of the Army.
Major Walter Reed is a professor
in the Army Medical School and could
not leave, at the time mentioned, to
attend, the health convention in Mich-
igan without serious interference
with the course of instruction pre-

ficers have been ordered to Washing-

G.M. Sternberg
Surgeon General, U.S. Army.
404591 -- A.G.O.
November 2, 1901.
Hon. R. P. Bishop, M. C.,
Ludington, Michigan.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of
the 24th ultimo, addressed to the Secretary of War, enclosing one
from Dr. V. C. Vaughan, of the Michigan University, requesting
that Major Walter Reed, Surgeon, U. S. Army, be detailed to attend
the conference of the Health Officers of the State of Michigan, to
be held at the University named on November 21st and 22nd, and,
in reply, the Secretary desires me to inform you that it is re-
gretted that it is impracticable to meet your wishes and those of
Dr. Vaughan in this matter, for the reason that, as reported by
the Surgeon General of the Army, Major Reed is a professor in the
Army Medical School in this city, and could not leave at the time
mentioned to attend the health convention in Michigan without
serious interference with the course of instruction prescribed.
Twenty young medical officers have recently been ordered to
Washington to take this course, and Major Reed's presence in
absolutely necessary during the entire month of November.
